Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Fabrication of Low-bandgap Nano-crystalline SiGeC Thin Films Using the Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PECVD) Technique
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This SBIR Phase II project is to develop thin film tandem solar cells, comprising of nanocrystalline silicon and silicon carbon (nc-Si and nc-Si:C) absorber materials, with a conversion efficiency of ~20%. The phase I project successfully developed one of the key components, i.e. intrinsic nc-Si:C with a band gap, Eg, of ~ 1.5 eV and with good opto-electronic properties. This key material will be used initially in phase II to fabricate cells in a single junction configuration with an efficiency goal of ~10%. Previously, developed "device quality" nc-Si materials, with Eg ~1.1eV, were used to produce solar cells with efficiency ~8%. Integrating the two devices in a tandem junction configuration is forecast to yield efficiencies of ~18%. Further improvement in the tandem junction device efficiency,to ~20%, may be achieved via the use of buffer layers at the p/i or i/n interfaces and by increasing the grain size which would boost the open circuit voltage, Voc.

Higher efficiency thin film tandem solar cells will be critical to achieving the low costs necessary to achieve widespread adoption of photovoltaic energy generating systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main drawback of the amorphous silicon (a-Si) thin film solar cell is its inherent degradation as the defect density of states within the energy bandgap increases with prolonged illumination.    As a result, the depletion width of the a-Si cell (constructed in a p-i-n configuration) decreases and the recombination of the photo-generated carriers in the intrinsic layer increases, leading to a smaller collection width and hence a reduction in the short-circuit current density (Jsc) and a lower conversion efficiency. To mitigate the instability problem, the a-Si devices are generally made in a tandem junction configuration where the a-Si device (as the top cell) is thin (typically 200-400 nm). However, this limits the Jsc of the tandem cell. Besides, the instability in the a-Si tandem solar cell remains.

In order to increase the efficiency of a-Si solar cells, it is evident that either the problem of light-induced degradation in a-Si needs to be solved, or the unstable a-Si component needs to be removed from the entire structure. Over the last three decades, extensive studies have been performed to understand the light-induced degradation effect but with limited success. In contrast, the use of nanocrystalline silicon (nc-Si) materials in a photovoltaic device has proven to be stable. These types of films contain fine grains in the range of 10-20 nm, embedded in an a-Si matrix. With an appropriate volume crystalline fraction (50-70%), nc-Si solar cells exhibit almost none or very little degradation. In addition, it is desired to develop other nano-crystalline silicon based thin film materials which are of an optical bandgap of 1.5-1.8 eV, as this could lead to low-cost, stable, and  high efficiency (> 20%) solar cells when incorporated into a viable tandem junction configuration, as our theoretical simulation shows. Our goal in this NSF funded project is to fabricate such a high efficiency thin film silicon tandem solar cell.

 

During the Phase I performance period, we had successfully fabricated nc-SiX thin films with bandgap of around 1.5 eV and desired dark (10-8-10-7 S/cm) and photoconductivity (10-5-10-4 S/cm). This has provided us with a solid basis on which we could move towards fabrication of stable, high efficiency thin-film Si solar cells in Phase II.

 

Using nc-SiX as absorber, we first fabricated nc-SiX devices of superstrate-type p-i-n configuration, on the textured ZnO (zinc oxide) substrates by the very-high-frequency (VHF) PECVD technique. The ZnO substrate acts as the front transparent electrode and for light trapping in order to increase photocurrent. The thin p-type nc-Si and n-type a-Si layers were used for creating the build-in electric field. The metal or ZnO/metal contact acts as a back reflector in order to further enhance the internal reflection of photons and increase the Jsc. With the Eg ~1.5 eV in nc-SiX, we have achieve an efficiency of ~7.5% (with the open-circuit voltage, Voc ~0.6V). Next, we fabricate the tandem solar cell comprising the nc-SiX solar cell (as the top cell) and the nc-Si solar cell (bottom cell). A highly conductive interlayer was introduced at the interface of two cells. The entirely nanocrystalline silicon based tandem device exhibits a conversion efficiency of ~8%.    

Compared with the proposed goal set for this project, the efficiency of both nc-SiX and nc-Si/nc-SiX solar cells is still low. The nc-SiX material is of more complicated microstructure than nc-Si and deposition of this material requires more sophisticate control of the process parameters. Hence fabrication of the high performance nc-SiX solar cell is very challenging.
